definitions.definition: no longer alive

examples.text: My mother's dead; she died in 2017.
a dead person/animal
dead leaves/wood/skin
Catherine's **dead body** lay peacefully on the bed.
He was **shot dead** by a gunman outside his home.
A high school shooting has **left **six students **dead**.
She was **pronounced dead** at the scene of the accident.
The poor child looks **more dead than alive**.
He was **missing, presumed dead**.
He **dropped dead** *(= died suddenly)* last week.
One short year later, Fred would be dead from a heart attack.
In ten years he'll be **dead and buried** as a politician.
By the time the police arrived, he was already dead.
I'm afraid he's quite dead.
The woman was found dead with a rope around her neck.
His wife lay dead beside him.
She had been struck dead by lightning.
The animal will sometimes escape danger by playing dead.
We didn't know whether the fish was dead or alive.

definitions.definition: not working because of a lack of power

examples.text: a dead battery
Suddenly the phone **went dead**.
John's mobile was completely dead.

definitions.definition: no longer believed in or aimed for

examples.text: Many believe the peace plan is dead.
Unfortunately racism is not yet dead.
Though the idea may be dead, it is far from being buried *(= people still talk about it, even though there is nothing new to say)*.

definitions.definition: belonging to the past; no longer practised or fashionable

examples.text: Is the Western a dead art form?
a dead language *(= one that is no longer spoken, for example Latin)*

definitions.definition: finished; not able to be used any more

examples.text: dead matches
There were two dead bottles of wine on the table.

definitions.definition: very quiet, without activity or interest

examples.text: There were no theatres, no cinemas, no coffee bars. It was dead as anything.

definitions.definition: without activity; with nobody buying or selling anything

examples.text: ‘The market is absolutely dead this morning,’ said one foreign exchange trader.
Winter is traditionally the dead season for the housing market.

definitions.definition: extremely tired; not well

examples.text: **half dead** with cold and hunger
She felt **dead on her feet** and didn't have the energy to question them further.

definitions.definition: unable to feel because of cold, etc.

examples.text: My left arm had **gone dead**.

definitions.definition: unable to feel or understand emotions

examples.text: He was dead to all feelings of pity.

definitions.definition: showing no emotion

examples.text: She said, ‘I'm sorry, too,’ in a quiet, dead voice.
His usually dead grey eyes were sparkling.

definitions.definition: complete or exact

examples.text: a **dead silence/calm**
the **dead centre** of the target
The car gave a sudden jerk and came to a **dead stop**.
Her face was a **dead giveaway** *(= made it very obvious)* that something was going on.
This horse is a **dead cert** for *(= will certainly win)* the race tomorrow.
She crumpled to the floor **in a dead faint** *(= completely unconscious)*.

definitions.definition: never having been alive

examples.text: dead matter *(= for example rock)*
a dead planet *(= one with no life on it)*

definitions.definition: outside the playing area

examples.text: There was a dead ball with five seconds to go in the game.

definitions.definition: to be dead

examples.text: You'll be sorry you said that when I'm dead and gone.
That won't happen until long after I'm dead and gone.

definitions.definition: to look very like somebody

examples.text: She's a dead ringer for a girl I used to know.

definitions.definition: completely dead; no longer interesting or relevant

examples.text: In the second half both teams made substitutions to try and liven things up, but the game was as dead as a dodo.

definitions.definition: completely dead
a plan, an event, etc. that has failed or is certain to fail and that is therefore not worth discussing
an influence that controls or limits something

examples.text: We need to free business from the dead hand of bureaucracy.

definitions.definition: a person or plan that is dead in the water has failed and has little hope of succeeding in the future

examples.text: His leadership campaign is dead in the water.

definitions.definition: in serious trouble

examples.text: If anyone finds out, you're dead meat.

definitions.definition: (of an accident victim or other patient) already dead when arriving at a hospital

examples.text: She was pronounced dead on arrival.
He didn’t even make it to hospital: DOA.
Many of the casualties were dead on arrival.

definitions.definition: very unlikely to be successful; not working when it is delivered

examples.text: The bill was dead on arrival in the Senate.
The software was DOA.

definitions.definition: in a deep sleep
to waste your effort by trying to do something that is no longer possible
to impress somebody very much

examples.text: You look fabulous—you'll knock ’em dead tonight.

definitions.definition: used to show you are strongly opposed to something

examples.text: She moves into our home over my dead body.

definitions.definition: used to say that you would not like to wear particular clothes, or to be in a particular situation

examples.text: She wouldn't be seen dead in a hat.
He wouldn't be caught dead going to a club with his mother.

wordOrigin: Old English dēad, of Germanic origin: related to Dutch dood and German tot, also to die.
